7-Man Army tells the story of seven Chinese soldiers (Ti Lung, Alexander Fu Sheng, Chen Kuan-Tai, David Chiang andÃ¢â‚¬Â¦ sorry, I canÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t name the other three) who defend a fortress against thousands of Japanese troops and Mongolian mercenaries (led by Leung Kar-Yan, Gordon Liu and Wang Lung-Wei).   The film is set in 1933, during JapanÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s initial occupation of China.

  Though not as Americanized as Boxer Rebellion, 7-Man Army is still a very much a high budget, epic-like, polished production. It features hundreds of extras, big explosions, and even actual fighter planes dropping bombs.

7-Man Army is obviously a war movie, but donÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t let the word Ã¢â‚¬ËœwarÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ fool you. Sure, it has the gun-battles, military jive and typical war film scenarios; but it equally qualifies as a good olÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ Shaw Brothers kung fu flick.
  In a way, itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s kind of funny Ã¢â‚¬â€œ during many instances, hand-to-hand combat is the primary weapon of choice for the soliders; and if itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s not with their bare hands (or feet), theyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ll still prefer to use their bayonets instead of just shooting the damn rifle Ã¢â‚¬â€œ as silly as it sounds, itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s acceptable because itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Chang Cheh.

Sporadically throughout, each of the seven men have their own little flashback segment (a la Bruce Lee, John Saxon and Jim Kelly in Enter The Dragon), explaining why they each joined the army.
  These mini stories help break up the war-setting a bit, making the filmÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s pace even better.

The finale packs one hell of a punch and if youÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re familiar with most of Chang ChehÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s work, it should come to no surprise that 7-Man Army ends with a great dose of heroic bloodshed.
  LetÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s just say that Willem DafoeÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s death scene in Platoon ainÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t got nothing on thisÃ¢â‚¬Â¦
